And the default is good until the scheduler sets something else.

I see that this was an agreement with Dan so I won't challenge it. It just feels strange to me that we are not initializing the object's fields during the __init__ of the object. I always thought about lazy-load in ovo as a db access optimization (do not do extra joins if the fields coming form the joined tables are never accessed). But here being lazy does not spare us anything but in the other hand contributes the magicness of ovo.
How about a nova-specific mixin for objects that can load up defaults generically (objects that aren't using the db persistence mixin class)?

Man, that's a damned good idea.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701795/

You're correct that it doesn't matter as much for this type of object. The problem is, it does matter for objects that we have where fields represent columns in the database. The reason ovo is designed the way it is (where all fields are optionally set, much like SQLA objects) is so that you can have an object that doesn't specify a field and not clobber that column in the database.

That doesn't matter here in the same way, but the distinction is fairly obscure and having things defaulted in __init__ provides examples for others to copy (and yes, we have other examples in the tree, which were copied and referenced here).

If we had some way to differentiate objects for which this detail doesn't matter, then I'd be cool with the obviously-easier method of defaulting those things in init (or better yet, making default= on the field behave more like you'd expect). Until we have that (which will likely involve ovo changes), sticking to a convention seems reasonable.

If you add an 'other' reno then I don't think a bug is probably necessary.

There isn't (that I know of), but it's also not a supported way of deploying today. When glance grows an image movement API (in the works now) then we can use that to implement a feature and call this an improvement in nova. Right now, this is just a circuit breaker to allow operators to cheat a little bit and not have nova do something pathologically stupid with their storage.

I can add a reno.

I thought workaround options were meant to be for known bugs but we don't have a bug reported for this otherwise I'd expect it to be linked in the commit message.

I think I addressed this in replies to the first time you asked about a bug.

Nova doesn't support multiple rbd stores. Fixing that would be a feature/bp, I wouldn't call it a bug that it doesn't support something. This is a workaround to help people avoid nova doing the stupid storage-munching thing if they configure their glance to have multiple backends (which glance does support).

If you think it's important to have a bug, then I can open one, but it'll be "nova does something dumb when you configure it in an unsupported way."

neutron/agent/l3/router_info.py.message: This method can be called from two separate threads; as you pointed in the bug, the first one deleting the subnet and the second one adding a new one with same CIDR. There is no guarantee that the deletion call is done before the addition one. IMO, just moving this code won't prevent both threads to be executed in any order.
The l3-agent should have queued both updates to the same thread since they are hashed by the router id, unless _process_routers_if_compatible() isn't working as i thought.

@Rodolfo, it's not exactly like that. In case of removing or adding new subnet to the router, even which comes to L3 agent is always router_update. And this triggers this method. So for one router it's always in one thread. And it than calculates and compares ports from cache and ports actually plugged to the router. So if we will change this order we should always first remove old port and than add new one which would solve the issue described in the related bug.

@Brian @Slawek, I missed that part: the update messages are queued in L3NATAgent._queue and the the "_process_routers_loop" spawns several threads to process those messages. But those related to the same router will be processed in the same one.

Knowing that, I'm ok with this patch.

common/container-puppet.py.message:
i don't see how a new hashed file gets created.

the "continue" here would cause the rest of the loop to get skipped. seems like you'd only want to do that if the hash hasn't changed, not if the hashed-* file already exists.
ok, that makes sense. i follow how it works now

Let's say we have on the host:

* haproxy.json
* hashed-haproxy.json

What do we want at the end is the haproxy.json to be hashed, so a new hashed-haproxy.json (which this patch would produce).

Unless I misunderstood something (maybe haproxy.json can be outdated?), hashed-haproxy.json was never updated.
See https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/1c1415689e67ac60661381748e3f0db75e2d333d/common/deploy-steps-tasks.yaml#L177 - we never used the hashed configs to be processed by the container-puppet.py script.

So I believe that this condition is needed to avoid having "hashed-hashed-haproxy.json" after a second config change.
this block is what updates the hashes, but it would have been skipped if they already exist, which means they'd never get updated.

heat/common/config.py.message: I don't think 'Default' is accurate here, since this overrides the region in the context (unlike the region_name_for_services option, which is a backup for when no region appears in the context).

I think it's reasonable to set this as the default, since it avoids having operators have to look up which service names they need to set here in the common case. However, it would be nice if the help message made it clearer that this option has no effect unless the region_name_for_shared_services option is also set.

heat/engine/clients/os/keystone/heat_key.message: It's weird to see a property named get_*. Given that all the uses of it are in this patch, couldn't we just make it a method?
I don't see this attribute get set anywhere in this class.
Assuming that this is used only by the keystone ClientPlugin, shouldn't we be passing the value in from there rather than duplicating the implementation above?

This is going to pick the shared services region if there are *any* shared services types, but surely we only want that if keystone is one of the shared service types? The client plugin already knows how to calculate this correctly, so it still seems to me that we should pass this in to the constructor from KeystoneClientPlugin._create().
It might pay to name this with a leading underscore, since auth_region_name is what we actually want consumers to use.

heat/engine/resource.py.message:
This was copied from ClientPlugin, but there is no self.service_types attribute on a Resource.

I don't think Resource is the right place to put this method, because in the two cases it's currently used, it is to get the region for a *different* service type (Heat itself) than the one that is used to create the resource.

heat/engine/resources/server_base.py.message: I'd be inclined to move the call to here (and line 101), since there's no guarantee that all transport types will use the same region (they may have different service_types for the return signal - I'm pretty sure the cfn one does).
This is wrong, because orchestration may not be one of the shared services types. I think what we want is to load the Heat client plugin and call its _get_region_name() method.
Oops, missed it last time. Done.

Not sure how to load the ClientPlugin and call the _get_region_name() method, being an abstract class it won't let me instantiate the class without implementing the _create method. The only way ClientPlugin is being used is by other clients is by inheriting it (and simply calling self._get_region_name()), but in this case it doesn't  look like the right thing to do.

IMO 
the resource client name will either to be this name or default_client_name. I believe will be a better option to just give no parameter for client_plugin() and leave it to default_client_name which will be `nova` in `OS::Nova::Server`. As for `OS::Heat::DeployedServer`, maybe just give it a `default_client_name = 'heat'`

your theory is correct after I tested it out. Will remove this qualification then.

I agree that the join condition should always be specified, at least for understandability of the code. I think the corner case that Thomas is referring to had to do with using the join condition to do filtering, which did not seem to work as intended.

ok in that case I will just revert it back to my original patch & just let Bob comment on that then. In my opinion, it might be a good idea to always specify the qualification to make it clear & easy to read. Thx.

Actually, I think I'm reconsidering my earlier statement - I seem to recall that Bob discovered that there can be corner cases if this qualification isn't used. I'll let him comment on that. If it ends up that's not the case, then you can probably also get rid of the same qualification in the join statement on lines 2294-2297 as well, as that's also a ForeignKey.

I think you may need to add some more code here - couldn't it be possible to remove and add AAPs in a single operation that could result in a valid configuration, whereas if you only consider the additions, it may not?

The API here is to prevent the same AAP address being added to a port which belongs to a different active_active_aap mode because if we allow it, it will become an user config error. We don't have the similar concern when the user tries to remove an AAP address from a port though.
Nit: spelling
Nit: This indentation does not look right. I think it should begin 4 characters to the right of the start of the previous line.
Nit: This indentation does not look right. I think it should begin 4 characters to the right of the start of the previous line.

Why is the project_id relevant here? I can't find any other places in the mechanism driver code where it is used as a filter in a query, and nothing in the RPC response related to AAPs is project-specific. In general, project_ids have no effect on the data plane semantics, just on who is allow allowed to use or see certain resources. Using project_id here seems wrong. It seems to me that only ports on the same network should be relevant, and those could be owned by different projects if the network is shared.

The API here is to prevent the same AAP address from being added to a port (within the same vrf) which belongs to a different active_active_aap mode. The reason I used project_id here is because in APIC, it translates to the same tenant which usually means the same vrf. Now thinking it a bit more, to make it absolutely right I need to consider,
1. if an address scope is used or not. This will involve querying the subnet_pool_id and corresponding address_scope_id.
2. if address scope is not used, use the vrf_name and vrf_tenant_name of the NetworkMapping table to do the query.

This will probably complicate this query quite a bit I think so I agree with u that its probably good enough to just enforce this within the same network instead of the whole vrf. Actually even in our meetings we agreed to check the network only but then I got agreesive while doing the implementation.....I will go ahead to make that change then unless you have some other ideas.
Nit: Actually, the AAAP attribute cannot be changed.
Nit: This query is not related to external networks, so should have its own block comment to be consistent with the style in this method.
Nit: missing period.
Nit: Missing period.
Nit: Capitalize.

glance/tests/unit/test_policy.py.message: In general I'm all for removing meaningless tests, but I'm not convinced that these two are those. By the quick look I did not find anywhere else us testing that overriding the "default" has actual effect. Perhaps we should rename these tests instead of removing them or am I missing something?

Shouldn't it be impossible for the "default" rule to ever be used?  I thought that the point of the policy-in-code effort was that when any policy action is defined in the code, it's defined along with a default value.  Since every policy action has its own default value, the "default" will never be activated.

> We don't create a rule named "default" any more, so this test was
 > failing.

Ok this is going to be a problem as this is backwards incompatible and potentially is very hazardous for lots of existing deployments. The "default" policy has been operating in a way that one can specify rule that gets applied everywhere and after that just overwrite what they want to deviate from that.

For example following policy.json file:
{
    "context_is_admin": "role:admin",
    "default": "role:admin",
    "get_image": "",
    "get_images": "",
    "download_image": "",
    "get_image_location": ""
}

would have previously allowed anyone consume images but not create, modify etc. (basically everything else) which would have been reserved for "role:admin". After this change, most of the privileges would be just silently granted to everyone.

We cannot just silently ignore "default" rule that applies everywhere and has been the basis for any sane policy file so far.

Can't this be specified in configuration instead? 

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/configuration/index.html#oslo_policy.policy_default_rule

> Shouldn't it be impossible for the "default" rule to ever be used? 
 > I thought that the point of the policy-in-code effort was that when
 > any policy action is defined in the code, it's defined along with a
 > default value.  Since every policy action has its own default
 > value, the "default" will never be activated.

Yeah - the whole policy-in-code effort makes specifying a default completely obsolete (in favor of something much more granular).

But, from a backward-compatibility perspective, if one is concerned about preserving a one-size-fits-all default, oslo.policy will do that for you with that configuration option (so the behavior is achievable even though it might not be recommended).

This test was testing what happens if the user provides an empty/nonexistent policy.json file instead of the in-tree one with the default policies, forcing us to rely on some default default policy (in the form of a rule named "default").

With the default policies now in code, it's no longer possible to not have the default policy available (you'd have to remove some code, not just the policy.json file), so there's nothing to test. We don't create a rule named "default" any more, so this test was failing.

releasenotes/notes/policy-in-code-7e0c6c.message:
Even though we don't recommend this...

Do operators know more granular defaults for glance policies are being developed?

It used to be the case that the policy_default_rule setting governed the *name* of the rule that was used in the situation where a target is being checked but a rule for that target does not exist.  So I don't see how setting this option will have any effect, since the rule is never going to be used because all the targets have rules defined in the code.
I apologize, I may have remembered that behavior differently. After dusting off the code and oslo.policy docs, Brian is right.

I interpreted Lance's response last time you asked this question as meaning that if you set this config option the defaults in code are ignored in favour of the configured default rule. If this interpretation were incorrect I assume Lance would have said so in his comment above.

Hi all:
Just demonstrate my personal viewpoint. Put haproxy driver aside, just consider Octavia's semantic, I think the listener is a user-oriented component, the value of listener protocol represents the capacity of the load_balancer provides to users, the pool is a backend-oriented component, it's protocol represents that the load balancer how to access backend member. The backend member can be a TCP, HTTP, HTTPS, UDP service，So the pool should support TCP, HTTP, HTTPS, UDP and PROXXY.
About the protocol combination, I think we should follow the below criterion: The listener's protocol should more basic protocols. For example, the TCP listener can be combined with HTTP pool, but the HTTP listener can't be combined with TCP pool.

manifests/profile/base/kernel.pp.message:
* ~> (notifying arrow; a tilde and a greater-than sign) — Applies the resource on the left first. If the left-hand resource changes, the right-hand resource will refresh.

* -> (ordering arrow; a hyphen and a greater-than sign) — Applies the resource on the left before the resource on the right.

Which means that with your patch, the exec will never run because it has "refreshonly".

If you just want to make sure that the "rebuild initramfs" runs every time; keep the ordering arrow and also remove the "refreshonly" from the exec. Although keep in mind that the exec will now run at every puppet run; which I'm not sure is wanted.
If the issue is a minor update issue, perhaps this needs to be included in the update tasks to always run a rebuild initramfs on update. I don't think this is the right spot to fix the referenced bug

openstackclient/tests/unit/volume/v2/tes.message: Why are you doing this for hard-coded values?  I do not see an improvement here

Okay, I try explain this through a simple example. This 
change is needed, because using % interpolates the string 
before the logging call, while using comma means that 
interpolation will happen in the logger's side. That means
logger is not called with a string, it is called with a 
(format) string and a dictionary mostly, which hold the 
values for the format string, and the logger will 
interpolate the values in the format string ONLY IF it is 
needed.

Here's a simple example: 

    def foo(*args):
        print('foo called with:')
        for arg in args:
            print(arg)
        print('------')

This is a simple function which can be called with almost 
everything. I will call it 2 different ways. The first one
is the way it was used in the codes:

    foo("1. My favorite number is %d, and my name is %s" % 
(42, "Earl"))

Because I used % to interpolate the string, the values will 
be replaced before calling the method, and the method will 
result in the following output:

    foo called with:
    1. My favorite number is 42, and my name is Earl
    ------

While the currently supported way is leave this 
interpolation to the logger. And the interpolation will only
happen when it needed, not every single time regardless the
logging level. So calling it in the new way:

    foo("2. My favorite number is %d, and my name is %s", 42, 'Earl')

The output will be the following:
    foo called with:
    2. My favorite number is %d, and my name is %s
    42
    Earl
    ------

That change caused that I needed to replace the old-kind call with this. However, you can also try the old test yourself, that will prove that this line needed to be changed.

I hope you understand now why I had to change this test.

Greetings,
Gábor

> Before this patch, the string was interpolated before the logging call, the logger was call was (1 parameter which is a string)

I really do not understand this statement.  where does interpolation happen with a single string constant?  I'm not a python guru, but I see no interpolation there.

Our primary purpose here is clear understandable code.  This sort of optimization in tests is secondary.

You're wrong. Before this patch, the string was interpolated before the logging call, the logger was call was (1 parameter which is a string): 

    LOG.error("1 of 2 volumes failed to add.")

And in this patchset, it is replaced by calling the logger with the format string, and the additional parameters, which is mostly a dictionary. And after all, the logger interpolates the string and replaces the the format parameters with the parameters from dictionary. It is done only when it needed. (For example, if your logging level is set to "error", then the "debug" messages will not be interpolated, no useless replaces happen.)

This cause that this assert had to be replaced, as the new logging call looks like (with 2 parameters, a format string, and a dictionary):

    LOG.error('%(result)s of %(total)s volumes failed to add.', {'result': 1, 'total': 2})
